summary: James W. McCord, Jr. was a CIA employee whose personnel file details his career assignments from 1948 to 1964. He was involved in the Office of Security and was reassigned along with Arthur C. Sheridan and James P. O'Connell, Jr. in 1965. McCord received an Honor and Merit Award for his work improving the Agency's Audio-countermeasures Program, specifically in the development of a new fluoroscopic scanning technique for detecting clandestine microphones. His file also contains documents related to his employment and involuntary retirement from the CIA in 1970, including performance reviews and commendations.
significance: Based on the provided documents, the significance of James W. McCord, Jr. in the JFK assassination context is not explicitly mentioned. The documents primarily focus on his CIA career, assignments, and recognition within the agency.
